Nanoscale materials have long promised to revolutionize science and technology, with claims being sustained by both the advances in their fabrication and by the many fundamental studies that have been carried out to date, which have revealed fascinating properties when materials dimensions shrink all the way down to a few hundreds/thousands of atoms. In this ongoing hype, on one side we have the futuristic views and promises of ubiquitous devices in which the operating units will be eventually scaled down to individual atoms or molecules. On the other side, we have the more realistic (and already unfolding) scenario represented by nanoscale materials making their way in a wide variety of applications (not always and not necessarily flagged as “high-tech”) where downsizing truly brings about new or improved features that can be immediately exploited for some practical use. These applications have encompassed fields as disparate as medicine, biology, energy conversion and storage, catalysis, sensing, nanocomposite engineering, cosmetics, to cite the most popular ones. For a new technology to be pervasive and disruptive, the costs associated to the fabrication, the characterization and the assemblage of its key components have to drop quickly over time, while at the same time the material quality and the reproducibility of the various processes must keep improving. In the case of nanomaterials, we have not yet witnessed such an ubiquitous revolution, and one of the reasons is probably the lack of straightforward and reproducible synthetic protocols providing large amounts of nanomaterials and thus capable of efficient up-scaling to fulfil industrial needs. Another reason likely resides in the growing concern that nanomaterials will pose new threats to the environment, but this aspect will not be investigated here.
In this review, we will touch upon the critical feature of nanomaterials science and engineering dealing with the high throughput synthesis, with a focus on materials prepared in the liquid phase, where the expertise of the authors of this review lays. As a note of caution to the reader, we will not cover in depth all existing approaches to large scale syntheses. Our discussion will be instead a broad summary of the main types of synthetic approaches developed to date, and which we believe will be useful to scientists and engineers who are approaching the fabrication of nanomaterials with an eye on their use in large-scale, industrial applications. The review has been written according to the principle “from the simple to the complex”: it begins with the simplest one-batch heat-up synthesis approach, followed by hot-injection methods and ends by discussing the more sophisticated continuous flow syntheses of nanoparticles. Similarly, in each section, wherever possible, the discussion will start from simpler compounds, (for example, one-component noble metal nanocrystals), and will then move on to more complex structures (from binary to ternary and even quaternary compounds, which will be mainly metal oxides and chalcogenides).

Over the last few decades, research on nanoparticles (NPs) has een a thriving area, with its inception inspired by a fascinating ndeavour: understanding the behaviour of a solid when its physial dimensions shrink to a chunk of only a few hundreds/thousands f atoms. In this size regime, the quantum mechanical coupling f the constituent atoms gives rise to new and interesting physcal phenomena. Over the years, intensive efforts by a plethora of esearch groups around the globe have made it possible to reach an utstanding level of control of these “quantum mechanical” properies by being able to tune the size, shape, structure and composition f many different types of materials at the nanoscale. What is more, he small size of NPs, coupled with their large surface-to-volume atio, makes them valuable contenders for several applications in
any different fields, for example, in electronics, optoelectronics, ensor technologies, photovoltaics, nanophotonics, catalysis and edicine [1–8]. Ligand-stabilized NPs, i.e. particles made of an norganic core and an organic shell of stabilizing ligands, are paricularly suitable candidates for low cost processing, as they can e employed in the form of liquid suspensions, for example as nks in printed electronics or as formulations in biomedical appliations. The recently published excellent reviews by Kagan et al. 9] and Yang et al. [10] summarize the state of the art methods of ntegration of various nanoparticles into functional devices.
Compared to a large body of fundamental research that has been evoted to nanomaterials over the years, in part fuelled by the probably excessive) hype on nanoscience and nanotechnology, the umber of applications that have made their way into consumer roducts has been relatively small so far. To a large extent, this is ue to one simple reason: making nanomaterials in large amounts s still difficult: for example, the reaction conditions for the syntheis of colloidal nanomaterials have to be meticulously controlled o produce monodisperse NPs, and there is a very narrow winow of variability of parameters for the nanoparticle properties to emain practically the same from batch to batch. Above all, the ossibility to tune their optical features by varying their size, shape, nd composition by simple chemical approaches is what has turned enerations of chemists into a race of developing more refined

Recently added members to the list of fluorescent QDs are represented by halide perovskite NPs. Halide perovskites have gathered impressive attention over the last few years for their unique properties that make them appealing in applications in photovoltaics, optoelectronics and lighting [12–15]. Initially evolved as thin films and bulk single crystals, they have soon been developed in nanocrystal form too, with the notable feature that NPs of some of these materials (especially the APbX3 ones, with A = methylammonium or Cs, X = Cl, Br, or I), have strong fluorescence [16–19]. Apart from QDs, many companies all over the world have commercialised the production of noble metal and magnetic nanomaterials, having in view their great perspective in biomedical applications, in particular in biosensing (noble metal NPs), magnetic resonance imaging and hyperthermia (magnetic NPs), as well as in catalysis.
In designing a synthesis route for nanomaterials for lab-scale research, the main focus is on targeting a desired composition with well-defined crystal phase, and stability in common solvents, through a process which can be carried out in a moderately well-equipped chemical laboratory, and in quantities sufficient for characterization, analysis and, in some cases, for the fabrication of a few prototype devices. This has made it possible to expand the knowledge on various nanomaterials and their potential applications. The know-how accumulated so far will provide directions for the future work and will help to identify materials that could be explored more extensively, with a synthesis process that can be industrially scalable. There have been many reports on colloidal synthetic approaches to various NPs based on relatively simple, generalized, inexpensive methods and employing nontoxic reagents. Many of these methods have been claimed to be easily scalable to prepare at least grams of product. When seen from an industrial perspective, the fabrication requirements are unfortunately not much promising, as they involve high temperatures, or the use of vacuum or yet inert atmosphere as typical operating conditions [20]. Therefore, scaling-up of successful laboratory-adapted protocols to an industrial level is often not straightforward, and there is still a strong demand for simpler and inexpensive methods for large-scale syntheses of high quality NPs [21]. For example, one of the pioneering methods for the synthesis of NPs made use of micelles [22]. This route is not very attractive for large scale industrial production, as it works at very low concentrations of reactants, it requires large amounts of surfactants, and multiple washing steps to remove unreacted species and surfactants.

Solution based colloidal synthesis has emerged as a separate ranch of synthetic chemistry due to the flexibility it offers with egards to preparing NPs of a broad range of materials and the xcellent control over the size and shape, in addition to employing
relatively simple experimental equipment. High quality materils can be produced through this method at surprisingly low cost. n a colloidal synthesis, suitable molecular precursors (which genrally comprise inorganic salts or organometallic compounds) are eacted in a liquid medium in the presence of stabilizing agents r capping ligands. The chain of chemical reactions involving the recursors in the synthesis medium ultimately frees reactive chemcal species, called monomers, which will be the ones responsible or the nucleation and the growth of the NPs [23–29]. A general olloidal synthetic strategy involves several consecutive steps: (a) ucleation, when a critical concentration of the active monomer pecies in the reaction mixture is reached; (b) growth, when the ormed nuclei do not dissolve back into monomeric units but nstead keep acquiring monomers from the solution phase and are urther enlarged in size; (c) arresting the growth − quenching of the eaction and separation of the particles from the reaction mixture, hen the desired size has been achieved; and (d) post-synthetic reatments, if necessary. It is important to temporally separate ucleation and growth in order to achieve a narrow size distriution of the NPs [30–32]. The chemical reactions which free the onomer species can be for instance the decomposition of moleclar precursors (in the case of QDs), the hydrolysis of salts with ubsequent oxidation (for metal oxide NPs), or the reduction of etal ions (in the synthesis of noble metal nanocrystals) [31]. In a ommon closed system lacking a continuous supply of reagents, the eparation between the nucleation and the growth stages is realzed by controlling the concentration of monomers in the system in uch a way that, after the nucleation has taken place, the concenration drops below a value that would prevent further nucleation vents, but that at the same time allows the nuclei to grow further nd not to dissolve instead. This is generally accomplished by reglating the rate at which the monomer species are released from he decomposition of the precursors.

One-batch synthesis
Two main routes can be defined in the one-batch synthesis: I) heat-up and II) hot-injection. Heat-up, the simplest approach, basically consists of heating a precursor (or a mixture of precursors) in high boiling solvents in the presence of appropriate stabilizing molecules, which control nucleation and growth of NPs. Here, the solvothermal synthesis approach can be classified as a subdivision of the heat-up technique, which, in addition to temperature, requires also a high pressure. This is usually developed by solvent vapours confined in a closed, hermetically sealed vessel. The hotinjection method implies instead a rapid injection of one of the precursors into a hot solution of another precursor dissolved in a heated mixture of high boiling point solvents (or injection of both precursors at once in a heated mixture of solvents) while the mixture is vigorously stirred. These conditions favour a burst of homogeneous nucleation, followed by growth of the NPs. These two approaches are reviewed in more detail in the following sections.
Heat-up method
This technique is suitable for the preparation of different materials, such as metal (e.g. Ag) [50], metal oxide, both magnetic (Fe3O4) and wide band gap semiconductor (ZnO, TiO2) [51], binary II–VI, III2-VI3 metal chalcogenide semiconductor (CdSe, Bi2Te3) [52,53], more complex ternary I-III-VI2 and even quaternary I2II-IV-VI4 alloyed semiconductor, such as CuInS2 (CIS) [54] and Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) [55,56] NPs. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of main examples of NPs prepared by the heat-up approach are presented in Fig. 2, which demonstrates the ability of this technique to produce fairly monodisperse particles not only of spherical shapes but also platelet-, bullet-, and tetrahedral-shaped nanocrystals. Below we provide some examples of these syntheses.

Solvothermal and microwave irradiation syntheses The solvothermal (with hydrothermal as a particular case of it) approach utilizes solvents under elevated pressures and temperatures, either above or below their critical point, to increase the solubility of solid precursors and to speed up reactions among them. The method uses a sealed reaction vessel. No matter how good quality control can be achieved, the solvothermal synthesis is relatively difficult to be applied in the large scale production of nanomaterials, due to its harsh reaction conditions. In the literature there are nonetheless a few reports on the large scale NP synthesis by this method. One example is represented by the highly crystalline hydrophilic and hydrophobic magnetic 20 nm Fe3O4 NPs exhibiting a room temperature magnetization as high as 84 emu/g [73]. According to this report, a single reaction could give 86% (1.4 g) or 68% (0.9 g) yields of hydrophilic and hydrophobic magnetite nanocrystals, respectively. These NPs not only had super-paramagnetic behaviour with notably high saturation magnetization, but also exhibited excellent performance in magnetic hyperthermia. Another example of potentially up-scalable process is the synthesis of Bi2S3 and Sb2S3 nanorods from single source precursors under air at relatively low reaction temperatures [74]. The authors, however, mentioned neither yield of the reaction at laboratory scale nor large scale production in the report.
Microwave irradiation methodology has been explored to synthesize various NPs, such as lanthanide orthophosphate nanorods [75], InGaP, InP and CdSe NPs [76], rods and wires of ZnS, ZnSe, CdS and CdSe [77], and rare earth oxide (M2O3, M = Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy) nanorods and nanoplates [78]. Most of them used conventional/cooking microwave ovens, which made the process rapid and simple, without the need of inert atmosphere or high pressure. The more uniform heating provided by microwave irradiation eliminates issues linked to thermal gradients in chemical synthesis, and thus the method is promising for preparing large quantities of various nanomaterials. Also, much higher heating rates can be achieved than with conventional heating, which therefore provides and additional means of tuning reactivity. Apparently, further upscaling of this synthesis to industrial amounts requires its implementation in a continuous reaction mode by coupling, for example, with the microfluidic systems that will be described in Section “Tubular flow reactors”.

Conclusions and outlook
In this review, we summarized the main methods for the colloidal synthesis of various nanomaterials that have demonstrated large scale production capabilities. Among the one-batch reaction modes, the heat up approach seems to be the most suitable for scale up, as it does not require rapid heat and mass transport within the reaction mixture, as instead for the hot-injection method. In general, although one-batch synthesis appears to be more adaptable to existing industrial infrastructures, it still suffers from inefficient heat management, especially in the case of high temperature reactions, as well as from inhomogeneous distribution of reactants in the case of large volumes of liquids processed, which eventually can lead to a poor process control. These issues can be surmounted by turning the synthesis into a continuous mode employing tubular or spinning disc reactors. Especially attractive is the application of microfluidic systems, which benefit from a better control owing to a small amount of reaction mixture processed at a time, and reduced hazard potential. At the same time, this small reaction volume can be disadvantageous, as it significantly decreases throughput of the system. Here, a further development is needed to adopt microfluidic reactors to scale up amounts of nanomaterials produced to meet industrial demands.
Having analysed the literature summarized in this review, we have to admit that it is quite difficult to define exact minimal spacetime production yields in the synthesis of colloidal nanomaterials, after which a system can be considered as a large scale production unit. It is mainly due to unspecified times and capabilities of the post-synthetic treatment of nanomaterials, especially their purification, which is unavoidable step of the whole process and which is highly time-consuming. Obviously, different materials require different processing and thus different times. Therefore, focusing solely on the reaction, a system with a throughput of at least one gram per hour we would evaluate as capable of large scale production. We note that this is a very rough estimation which does not need to be considered literally. Also, important is the potential for upscale which is quite obvious in the case of flow synthesis, although in order to make it large scale a continuous, uninterrupted supply of precursors should be further developed.

metadata.abstractText: Nanoscale materials have long promised to revolutionize science and technology, with claims being sustained by both the advances in their fabrication and by the many fundamental studies that have been carried out to date, which have revealed fascinating properties when materials dimensions shrink all the way down to a few hundreds/thousands of atoms. In this ongoing hype, on one side we have the futuristic views and promises of ubiquitous devices in which the operating units will be eventually scaled down to individual atoms or molecules. On the other side, we have the more realistic (and already unfolding) scenario represented by nanoscale materials making their way in a wide variety of applications (not always and not necessarily flagged as “high-tech”) where downsizing truly brings about new or improved features that can be immediately exploited for some practical use. These applications have encompassed fields as disparate as medicine, biology, energy conversion and storage, catalysis, sensing, nanocomposite engineering, cosmetics, to cite the most popular ones. For a new technology to be pervasive and disruptive, the costs associated to the fabrication, the characterization and the assemblage of its key components have to drop quickly over time, while at the same time the material quality and the reproducibility of the various processes must keep improving. In the case of nanomaterials, we have not yet witnessed such an ubiquitous revolution, and one of the reasons is probably the lack of straightforward and reproducible synthetic protocols providing large amounts of nanomaterials and thus capable of efficient up-scaling to fulfil industrial needs. Another reason likely resides in the growing concern that nanomaterials will pose new threats to the environment, but this aspect will not be investigated here. In this review, we will touch upon the critical feature of nanomaterials science and engineering dealing with the high throughput synthesis, with a focus on materials prepared in the liquid phase, where the expertise of the authors of this review lays. As a note of caution to the reader, we will not cover in depth all existing approaches to large scale syntheses. Our discussion will be instead a broad summary of the main types of synthetic approaches developed to date, and which we believe will be useful to scientists and engineers who are approaching the fabrication of nanomaterials with an eye on their use in large-scale, industrial applications. The review has been written according to the principle “from the simple to the complex”: it begins with the simplest one-batch heat-up synthesis approach, followed by hot-injection methods and ends by discussing the more sophisticated continuous flow syntheses of nanoparticles. Similarly, in each section, wherever possible, the discussion will start from simpler compounds, (for example, one-component noble metal nanocrystals), and will then move on to more complex structures (from binary to ternary and even quaternary compounds, which will be mainly metal oxides and chalcogenides). © 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
